Detailed Description

Drawable is any 2D element shown on screen that is not part of the game world.

Note
drawable_init() Must be called for using the Drawable API.

Usage

For example, the ammo counter is a Drawable, an enemy or barrel is not. More specifically, Drawable provides high-level functions to easily draw a texture (known in DOOM jargon as a patch) to the screen. Fundamentally every on-screen element (that is not part of the gameworld) is one or more textures (patches) all the way down.

Example

Before creating a Drawable, the Drawable API must be initialized. Unless you're off the beaten path, it will already be initialized by the engine at start time.

// drawable_init(); Somewhere else the engine calles this function to initialize the API for
// us to use.
Drawable *drawable = drawable_create();
drawable_create
Drawable * drawable_create(Drawable drawable)
Creates a Drawable for displaying a DrawableTexture to the screen.
Drawable
Definition: drawable.h:146

If we're drawing a texture such as the icon for the blue keycard, we simply use the Drawable type and assign its texture to the blue keycard texture found in the WAD.

However, DOOM doesn't support the loading or drawing of abritrary fonts and images on the filesystem. Those must be textures of some kind, and they must exist in the WAD. So, if we want to draw numbers or strings to the screen, (whether they be used as ammo counters in the case of numbers, menu items or chat messages in the case of strings, etc) we're really drawing a series of individual textures for each alphanumeric symbol.

To expand upon the basic functionality of texture loading and drawing provided by Drawable, a member sub_type (DrawableSubType) is present. This is an enum containing values for valid sub-types. If no sub-type is being used, the enum value is simply DRAWABLE.

Examples of such sub-types are those used to faciliate drawing numbers and strings in a high- level manner. A sub-type value of NUMBER denotes that a NumberDrawable will be used. A sub-type value of TEXT denotes that a TextDrawable will be used. If no sub-type will be used, the value is just DRAWABLE.

◆ drawable_init()

void drawable_init ( )

Initialize the Drawable API.

The initialization function is responsible for the loading of any textures found in a WAD that a developer may wish to draw. It also is responsible for initializing a Registry used to keep track of all Drawables.

Note
Generally, this function will already be called by the engine init, and you shouldn't need to call it yourself unless you're doing something special.

Variable Documentation

◆ large_numbers

DrawableTextures::large_numbers

Textures for the large red numbers (0 through 9), used in Drawables such as the health counter. They can be viewed by looking at lumps STTNUM<x> in a WAD editor.

◆ small_numbers

DrawableTextures::small_numbers

Textures for the small yellow numbers (0 through 9) used in the small ammo counters. They can be viewed by looking at lumps STYSNUM<x> in a WAD editor.

◆ status_bar

DrawableTextures::status_bar
Warning
If there is no STBAR lump in your WAD, you're not going to be able to use this.

The background texture for the status bar.

Note
Inside the WAD, this texture must exist as a lump called STBAR. For reference, here is what the original texture looks like from DOOM.
Note that the texture actually assumes a multiplayer game is happening - there is a frag counter in place of where the arms counter / weapon inventory usually is. This is actually a secondary texture called STARMS that is simply drawn over the status bar when not in deathmatch.
